questions.text: A patient is being treated with phenobarbitone. Which of the following is inhibited? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Complex I → coenzyme Q


Phenobarbitone is known to affect the electron transport chain, specifically inhibiting the transfer of electrons from Complex I to coenzyme Q. Complex I, also known as NADH dehydrogenase and NADH CoQ oxidoreductase, takes hydrogen from NADH and transfers electrons to coenzyme Q (ubiquinone). This step is crucial in the electron transport chain as it initiates the flow of electrons, which is essential for ATP production. Phenobarbitone inhibits this specific step, disrupting the electron flow, which impairs cellular energy production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Complex II → coenzyme Q: This step involves the transfer of electrons from succinate to coenzyme Q, a different pathway not directly affected by phenobarbitone.

 

Option C. Complex III → Cyt. C: This step transfers electrons from coenzyme Q to cytochrome C, an independent part of the electron transport chain not impacted by phenobarbitone.

 

Option D. Complex IV → oxygen: This final step involves the transfer of electrons to oxygen, forming water. Phenobarbitone does not inhibit this part of the chain.

 

Educational Objective:


Phenobarbitone specifically inhibits the electron transport between Complex I and coenzyme Q, disrupting ATP production.

choices.text: It has multiple reducing ends
It can be stored at multiple organs
It can provide glucose for about 1 week when needed

questions.text: Glucose is stored in the form of glycogen because? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is compact

 

Glycogen is a multibranched polysaccharide of glucose that serves as a form of energy storage in animals, fungi, and bacteria. It is the main storage form of glucose in the human body as it is compact.

 

In humans, glycogen is made and stored primarily in the cells of the liver and skeletal muscle. Liver glycogen helps to maintain the blood glucose levels in the fasting state. Most of the liver glycogen gets depleted after 18hrs of fasting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It has multiple reducing ends: Glycogen has multiple non-reducing ends, which facilitate rapid mobilization of glucose, not reducing ends.

 

Option C. It can be stored at multiple organs: Glycogen is mainly stored in the liver and skeletal muscles, not in multiple organs.

 

Option D. It can provide glucose for about 1 week when needed: Liver glycogen stores are typically depleted after about 18 hours of fasting, not 1 week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen is stored in a compact form, allowing efficient storage of large amounts of glucose in liver and muscle cells, enabling rapid mobilization of glucose when needed.

questions.text: Chronic alcoholic patient presented with confusion, Wernicke's aphasia and unstable gate. Patient has deficiency of:(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vit B1

 

The presentation of confusion, Wernicke's aphasia (a type of language impairment), and an unstable gait (ataxia) is highly indicative of Wernicke's encephalopathy, a condition commonly associated with chronic alcoholism and thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency. Alcoholism can lead to poor dietary intake and impaired absorption of thiamine, making this deficiency particularly common in this population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy, which is characterized by symptoms like bleeding gums, bruising, poor wound healing, and fatigue. While severe scurvy can affect mental status, it does not typically present with Wernicke's aphasia or ataxia.

 

Option C. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency is primarily associated with bone disorders like rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults. It can also contribute to muscle weakness and pain, but it does not typically cause confusion, language impairment, or ataxia as seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Vitamin B3 deficiency leads to pellagra, characterized by the "three Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. While dementia could overlap with confusion, pellagra does not typically present with Wernicke's aphasia or ataxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The symptoms described, including confusion, Wernicke's aphasia, and an unstable gait, are indicative of Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which is often associated with thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Chronic alcoholism can lead to poor nutritional intake and impaired absorption of essential nutrients, including thiamine. Thiamine is essential for the metabolism of glucose, and its deficiency can result in neurological symptoms.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 542

questions.text: A patient presented with diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies would you suspect in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B3 deficiency

 

The given clinical scenario of a patient with diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia is suggestive of niacin/vitamin B3 deficiency. Vitamin B3 (also called niacin, nicotinic acid)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B1/Thiamine deficiency: can manifest as wet beriberi (CVS features like heart failure and edema), dry beriberi (peripheral neuritis), or as Wernicke encephalopathy with Korsakoff psychosis (in alcoholics). Dietary deficiency of thiamine inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6/Pyridoxine deficiency: causes Convulsions, hyperirritability, peripheral neuropathy (deficiency inducible by isoniazid and oral contraceptives), sideroblastic anemia (due to impaired hemoglobin synthesis and iron excess)

 

Option D. Vitamin B12/Cobalamin deficiency: causes Macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia, paraesthesia and subacute combined degeneration due to abnormal myelin. Associated with

↑ serum homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels, along with 2° folate deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which molecule is required for recycling L-citrulline back to L-arginine in the nitric oxide pathway? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Argininosuccinate
 

Explanation:

 

In the nitric oxide (NO) pathway, L-citrulline produced from NO synthesis can be recycled back to L-arginine through the citrulline-NO cycle. This recycling process requires argininosuccinate as an intermediate. The conversion occurs in two steps:

 

  1. L-citrulline + Aspartate → Argininosuccinate (catalyzed by argininosuccinate synthetase)
  2. Argininosuccinate → L-arginine + Fumarate (catalyzed by argininosuccinate lyase)


 

Other Options:


 

Option B. Ornithine: While ornithine is involved in the urea cycle and is structurally similar to citrulline, it is not directly involved in the recycling of citrulline to arginine in the NO pathway.


 

Option C. Aspartate: Although aspartate is required for the conversion of citrulline to argininosuccinate, it is not the intermediate molecule that directly forms arginine. It serves as a substrate but not as the recycling intermediate.


 

Option D. Fumarate: Fumarate is a byproduct of the conversion of argininosuccinate to arginine, not the molecule required for recycling citrulline back to arginine.


 

Educational Objective:


 

The citrulline-NO cycle is crucial as it helps maintain continuous NO production. The recycling pathway involves argininosuccinate as a key intermediate, which is formed by the condensation of citrulline and aspartate, and then cleaved to form arginine and fumarate.

questions.text: Excess ammonia reduces which of the following substrates of the Krebs cycle?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alpha ketoglutarate

 

Excess ammonia has been shown to inhibit alpha-ketoglutarate. Ammonia interferes with the normal functioning of the Krebs cycle by inhibiting key enzymes, including those involved in the conversion of alpha-ketoglutarate. This disruption in the Krebs cycle can lead to metabolic imbalances and other health issues.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malate: Excess ammonia does not directly reduce malate. Malate is a key intermediate in the Krebs cycle but is not typically affected by ammonia levels.

 

Option B. Oxaloacetate: Excess ammonia does not directly reduce oxaloacetate either. Oxaloacetate is another intermediate in the Krebs cycle and is not a primary target of ammonia toxicity.

 

Option C. Fumarate: Similar to malate and oxaloacetate, fumarate is not a direct target of excess ammonia. It plays a role in the Krebs cycle but is not significantly affected by ammonia levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the CNS, Alpha ketoglutarate can combine with excess ammonia forming glutamate to reduce ammonia levels.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy rapidly develops hypoglycemia after moderate activity. Blood examination reveals raised levels of ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides. On examination, the liver and kidneys are found to be enlarged. Histopathology of the liver shows deposits of glycogen in an excess amount. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Von Gierke's disease

 

Clinical features are suggestive of Von Gierke’s disease (type I)

 

Salient features of Von Gierke’s Disease –

 

  • It is the most common type of glycogen storage disease.
  • Glucose-6-phosphatase is deficient.
  • Fasting hypoglycemia that does not respond to stimulation by adrenaline. The glucose cannot be released from liver during overnight fasting .
  • Clinical Features: Hyperlipidemia, lactic acidosis and ketosis.
  • Glucose-6-phosphate is accumulated, so it is channeled to HMP shunt pathway producing more ribose and more purine nucleotides.
  • Purines are then catabolized to uric acid, leading to hyperuricemia
  • Glycogen gets deposited in liver. Massive liver enlargement may lead to cirrhosis.
  • Children usually die in early childhood.
  • Renomegaly

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pompe's disease: This is a glycogen storage disease characterized by a deficiency of acid alpha-glucosidase. It primarily affects muscles and causes cardiomegaly but does not present with the same biochemical profile as Von Gierke’s disease.

 

Option C. McArdle's disease: This is characterized by a deficiency in muscle phosphorylase and primarily affects muscle metabolism, leading to muscle cramps and myoglobinuria after exercise, but not the described biochemical abnormalities or hepatomegaly.

 

Option D. Cori's disease: Also known as Forbes disease or glycogen storage disease type III, it is caused by a deficiency of the debranching enzyme. While it can cause hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia, it does not present with the specific profile of ketonemia, lactic acidosis, and hyperlipidemia seen in Von Gierke's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following shows functional assessment of B1 deficiency? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. RBC Transketolase

 

In thiamine deficiency, erythrocyte transketolase activity is reduced; this is the earliest manifestation seen even before clinical disturbances. Addition of thiamine diphosphate in vitro to erythrocyte lysate resulting in activation of apo transketolase is suggestive of B1 deficiency.

 

Thiamine contains a substituted pyrimidine ring connected to a substituted thiazole ring by means of methylene bridge. The vitamin is then converted to its active co-enzyme form by addition of two phosphate groups, with the help of ATP. It is catalyzed by thiamine pyrophosphotransferase.

 

Physiological Role of Thiamine

 

  1. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: The co-enzyme form is thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP). It is used in oxidative decarboxylation of alpha keto acids, e.g. pyruvate dehydrogenase catalyzes the breakdown of pyruvate, to acetyl CoA, and carbon dioxide
  2. Alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: An analogous biochemical reaction that requires TPP is the oxidative decarboxylation of alpha ketoglutarate to succinyl CoA and CO2
  3. Transketolase: The second group of enzymes that use TPP as co-enzyme are the transketolases, in the hexose monophosphate shunt pathway of glucose
  4. The main role of thiamine (TPP) is in carbohydrate metabolism. So, the requirement of thiamine is increased along with higher intake of carbohydrates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RBC Glutathione Reductase:

  • Function: Measures the activity of riboflavin (Vitamin B2).
  • Relevance: Used to assess riboflavin deficiency, not thiamine deficiency.

 

Option C. Serum Thiamine Levels:

  • Function: Direct measurement of thiamine in the blood.
  • Relevance: While it can indicate thiamine levels, it is less specific than functional assays like erythrocyte transketolase activity for assessing functional deficiency.

 

Option D. RBC Glutathione Peroxidase:

  • Function: Measures the activity of selenium and glutathione metabolism.
  • Relevance: Used to assess selenium status, not thiamine deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following defects causes familial hypercholesterolemia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LDL receptor

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is primarily caused by a defect in the LDL receptor or Apo B100 protein. The LDL receptor plays a crucial role in the regulation of cholesterol levels in the blood by mediating the uptake of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) particles into cells, particularly in the liver. When the LDL receptor is defective or absent, LDL particles cannot be effectively removed from the bloodstream, leading to elevated cholesterol levels, which predispose individuals to atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease. This condition is also known as type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apo E: Defects in Apo E are associated with type III hyperlipoproteinemia, not familial hypercholesterolemia. Apo E is important for the clearance of chylomicron remnants and VLDL from the bloodstream.

 

Option B. Apo CII: Apo CII is an activator of lipoprotein lipase, which is essential for the hydrolysis of triglycerides in lipoproteins. Deficiency in Apo CII leads to type I hyperlipoproteinemia (familial hyperchylomicronemia), characterized by elevated chylomicrons and triglycerides, not familial hypercholesterolemia.

 

Option D. Apo B48: Apo B48 is involved in the formation and secretion of chylomicrons from the intestine. It is not related to the development of familial hypercholesterolemia, which involves defects in the LDL receptor or related proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is caused by a defect in the LDL receptor, leading to elevated levels of LDL cholesterol in the blood and increased risk of atherosclerosis.

questions.text: Which gene is not involved in double strand DNA break repair mechanism? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MSH2

 

MSH2 stands for "MutS homolog 2." The gene is located on chromosome 2 and is not directly involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks. Instead, MSH2 is a key component of the DNA mismatch repair (MMR) pathway. MMR is responsible for correcting errors that occur during DNA replication, such as mismatches and small insertions or deletions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BRCA1: BRCA1 (Breast Cancer 1) is involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks through the homologous recombination pathway. Mutations in the BRCA1 gene are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancers.

 

Option C. KU70: KU70, along with KU80, forms the Ku heterodimer (Ku70/Ku80), which is a crucial component of the non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) pathway. NHEJ is a major mechanism for repairing double-strand DNA breaks, especially in the G1 phase of the cell cycle.

 

Option D. ATM: The ATM (ataxia-telangiectasia mutated) gene codes for a protein kinase that plays a central role in the cellular response to double-strand DNA breaks. It activates a signaling cascade that leads to DNA repair and cell cycle control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 understand the roles of different genes and proteins in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks (DSBs), which is essential for maintaining genome stability and preventing mutations.

questions.text: Following are reasons for biotin deficiency Except: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Low-fat diet

 

Explanation:

 

A low-fat diet is not directly associated with biotin deficiency. Biotin is a water-soluble vitamin, and its absorption is not dependent on dietary fat intake. Biotin can be obtained from various food sources regardless of their fat content, including nuts, seeds, legumes, and vegetables.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inflammatory Bowel Disease: IBD, particularly Crohn's disease, can cause biotin deficiency due to malabsorption in the intestine. The inflammation and damage to the intestinal mucosa impair the absorption of various nutrients, including biotin.

 

Option B. Raw Egg White Consumption: Raw egg whites contain avidin, a protein that binds strongly to biotin and prevents its absorption. Chronic consumption of raw egg whites can lead to biotin deficiency. This is not an issue with cooked eggs as heat denatures avidin.

 

Option D. Antibiotic Use: Long-term antibiotic use can disrupt the gut microbiota, which normally produces biotin. Additionally, some antibiotics can directly interfere with biotin metabolism or absorption, potentially leading to deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biotin deficiency can be caused by:

  • Intestinal malabsorption conditions
  • Consumption of substances that interfere with biotin absorption (like raw egg whites)
  • Antibiotic use affecting gut flora
  • Long-term parenteral nutrition
  • Genetic disorders of biotin metabolism
  • Anticonvulsant medications
  • Pregnancy and lactation (increased requirements)

questions.text: If percentage of thymine residues in DNA is 28%. what is the percentage of cytosine?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 22%

 

Explanation:

 

  • By Chargaff’s rule, number of purines equal the number of pyrimidines in a double stranded DNA. So, amount of Adenine = Thymine. As Thymine is given as 28%, so total A+T is 56%.
  • Now also, amount of Guanine = Cytosine, as they pair with each other by three hydrogen bonds.
    Remaining 44% (100-56) equally distributed in 22% each for guanine and cytosine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In DNA, thymine (T) always pairs with adenine (A), forming a complementary base pair. Similarly, cytosine (C) always pairs with guanine (G). The base pairing in DNA is always complementary, and the total percentage of purines (adenine + guanine) equals the total percentage of pyrimidines (thymine + cytosine).

questions.text: Identify the phenomenon shown below? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Complementation

 

The image shows a blue-white assay which uses the phenomenon of complementation (complementation of the galactosidase gene).

 

Blue-white assay: The target DNA is inserted into a vector. Vector is introduced into host cells for transformation and it grows in the presence of X-gal (X-gal detects active galactosidase). White colonies arise when cells are transformed with recombinant DNA-containing vectors; blue colonies form when cells are transformed with non-recombinant plasmids (i.e., just the vector).

 

Interpretation of Colonies:

 

  • White Colonies: These arise when the lacZ gene is disrupted by the insertion of foreign DNA, preventing the production of active beta-galactosidase. This indicates successful insertion of the foreign DNA.
  • Green Colonies: (Typically represented as blue colonies in traditional descriptions) These form when the lacZ gene remains intact, producing active beta-galactosidase that cleaves X-Gal, resulting in a blue color. This indicates the vector did not take up the foreign DNA or the insert is outside the lacZ gene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Translation: This process involves the synthesis of proteins from mRNA and is not related to the phenomenon shown in the image.

 

Option B. Transformation: While transformation is a part of the process where bacterial cells take up the plasmid DNA, the specific phenomenon depicted is complementation in the blue-white screening assay.

 

Option D. Conjugation: This is a method of horizontal gene transfer in bacteria involving direct cell-to-cell contact and is unrelated to the process shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The blue-white screening assay uses the complementation of the beta-galactosidase gene to distinguish between bacterial colonies with recombinant and non-recombinant plasmids based on the color change in the presence of X-Gal.

questions.text: Aspartate forms which of the following intermediate of TCA cycle:(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oxaloacetate

 

Aspartate can be converted into oxaloacetate through transamination. This reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme aspartate aminotransferase (AST). Oxaloacetate is a key intermediate in the TCA cycle and is also involved in gluconeogenesis. It can condense with acetyl-CoA to form citrate, thus participating in the TCA cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Citrate: Citrate is the first intermediate of the TCA cycle, formed by the condensation of acetyl-CoA and oxaloacetate. Aspartate does not directly form citrate. Instead, citrate is generated through the actions of citrate synthase at the beginning of the TCA cycle.

 

Option B. Alpha-Keto Glutarate: Alpha-ketoglutarate is an intermediate in the TCA cycle, but it is not directly formed from aspartate. It is produced from isocitrate through oxidative decarboxylation. Although aspartate can feed into the production of other TCA cycle intermediates, it does not directly convert into alpha-ketoglutarate.

 

Option D. Glutamate: Glutamate is an amino acid and not an intermediate of the TCA cycle. Although it is involved in amino acid metabolism and can undergo transamination reactions with various compounds, it is not a direct product of aspartate metabolism in the context of the TCA cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspartate an amino acid can be converted to oxaloacetate, an intermediate of the cycle. The conversion of aspartate to oxaloacetate is catalyzed by the enzyme aspartate transaminase.

 

 

Therefore, aspartate forms glutamate as an intermediate in the TCA cycle.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 160

questions.text: What is the repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-homologous end joining

 

NHEJ is the primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9. When CRISPR-Cas9 induces double-strand breaks in DNA, NHEJ rejoins the broken DNA ends, often introducing insertions or deletions (indels) at the repair site. This can result in gene knockout or disruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Base excision repair (BER): BER is a DNA repair mechanism that corrects damaged or mismatched bases in the DNA. It primarily deals with single-base changes and small DNA lesions. CRISPR-Cas9, on the other hand, creates double-strand breaks, so BER is not directly involved in repairing these breaks.

 

Option B. Nucleotide excision repair (NER): NER is another DNA repair mechanism that mainly deals with the removal of larger DNA lesions, such as those caused by UV radiation. It is not the primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9-induced double-strand breaks.

 

Option D. Mismatch repair (MMR): MMR is a repair mechanism that corrects errors in DNA replication, specifically base-pair mismatches and small insertion-deletion loops. It is not the primary mechanism involved in repairing double-strand breaks created by CRISPR-Cas9.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9 is non-homologous end joining (NHEJ), which repairs double-strand breaks by ligating the broken DNA ends, potentially causing insertions or deletions that disrupt the target gene.

questions.text: Eicosanoids are formed from:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arachidonic acid

 

Eicosanoids are derived from arachidonic acid, which is a polyunsaturated fatty acid found in cell membranes. Arachidonic acid serves as the precursor for eicosanoid synthesis when it is released from membrane phospholipids through the action of enzymes such as phospholipase A2. Once released, arachidonic acid can be metabolized into various eicosanoids, including prostaglandins, leukotrienes, and thromboxanes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Platelet aggregation: Platelet aggregation refers to the process of blood platelets clumping together. While eicosanoids can influence platelet aggregation by promoting or inhibiting it, they are not formed directly from platelet aggregation. Platelet aggregation involves the activation of platelets and the release of various signaling molecules, including some eicosanoids, as part of the clotting process.

 

Option C. 4 fused rings: Eicosanoids are not characterized by having four fused rings. Instead, they are typically small molecules with a 20-carbon backbone structure.

 

Option D. Arginine: Arginine is an amino acid and is not directly involved in the formation of eicosanoids. Eicosanoids are primarily derived from arachidonic acid, as mentioned earlier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eicosanoids are bioactive lipid molecules that play a crucial role in various physiological processes in the body. They are formed from arachidonic acid. Arachidonic acid has (20 C, 4=) and is synthesized from linoleic acid. Eicosanoids (Prostaglandins and leukotrienes) are synthesized from arachidonic acid. So, Linoleic acid is considered as most essential fatty acid.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 224

questions.text: A patient with C/O muscle weakness came to OPD. Doctor found he has cardiomyopathy & diagnosed him to be a case of Barth syndrome, where patient has mitochondrial dysfunction. What is the defect in this patient: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cardiolipin

 

Barth syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that primarily affects males and is caused by mutations in gene responsible for the production of an enzyme involved in cardiolipin synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lecithin is a common phospholipid found in various tissues and cell membranes, but it is not specifically associated with Barth syndrome or mitochondrial dysfunction.

 

Option C. Lysolecithin is a derivative of lecithin that is formed when lecithin is hydrolyzed. It is not directly related to Barth syndrome or mitochondrial dysfunction.

 

Option D. Cephalin is a term that refers to a group of phospholipids present in cell membranes, but it is not specifically linked to Barth syndrome or mitochondrial dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cardiolipin is a unique phospholipid primarily found in the inner mitochondrial membrane, where it plays a crucial role in maintaining mitochondrial structure and function.
  • The defective cardiolipin affects several mitochondrial processes, including energy production, electron transport chain function, and mitochondrial membrane stability. 
  • C/f
    • Muscle weakness
    • Neutropenia
    • Cardiomyopathy

questions.text: Glycosylated Hb (Hb-A1c) is best detected by: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ion exchange

 

Ion exchange chromatography is a highly effective method for detecting glycosylated hemoglobin (Hb-A1c). This technique separates hemoglobin molecules based on their net charge differences. Hb-A1c, which is glycated hemoglobin, has a different net charge compared to non-glycated hemoglobin. As a result, it can be quantified accurately using ion exchange chromatography. This method is widely accepted and used in clinical laboratories for monitoring long-term blood sugar control in diabetic patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Affinity chromatography: Affinity chromatography relies on the specific binding between a molecule of interest and a ligand immobilized on a chromatography column. While affinity chromatography can be used for various biomolecular separations, it is not the method of choice for detecting Hb-A1c. The affinity column would need to have a specific ligand that binds selectively to Hb-A1c, and this approach is less commonly employed compared to ion exchange chromatography for this purpose.

 

Option C. Isoelectric focussing: Isoelectric focussing is a technique that separates proteins based on their isoelectric points (pI), which is the pH at which a protein carries no net electrical charge. While this method can separate different hemoglobin variants based on their pI values, it may not be as precise as ion exchange chromatography for quantifying Hb-A1c specifically, as it relies on charge differences related to pI rather than glycation.

 

Option D. Electrophoresis: Electrophoresis is a general technique for separating molecules based on their charge and size differences in an electric field. Hemoglobin electrophoresis can separate different hemoglobin variants, including Hb-A1c, based on their charge differences. However, it may not provide the same level of specificity and accuracy as ion exchange chromatography when it comes to quantifying Hb-A1c.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HPLC based methods are gold standards for measurement of Hb-A1c. These methods further include ion exchange and affinity chromatography-based methods of which Ion exchange method is considered as the best and widely used method followed by affinity chromatography and enzymatic and immunological methods.

 

Ref- https://www.japi.org/v264/hba1c-result-does-it-depend-upon-the-testing-methods-

questions.text: Proteins are sorted by: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Golgi Bodies

 

Explanation: 

 

The Golgi apparatus (Golgi bodies) functions as the primary sorting and distribution center for cellular proteins. After proteins are synthesized by ribosomes and processed in the endoplasmic reticulum, they are transported to the Golgi apparatus where they undergo further modifications like glycosylation. The Golgi then packages proteins into transport vesicles and directs them to their appropriate destinations within or outside the cell based on specific sorting signals. Localization sequences within proteins serve as molecular "zip codes" that the Golgi recognizes to ensure proper targeting to destinations such as the plasma membrane, lysosomes, or for secretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mitochondria: While mitochondria import specific proteins targeted to them, they do not function as general protein sorting organelles for the cell. Mitochondria are primarily involved in energy production through oxidative phosphorylation and contain their own genome and protein synthesis machinery.

 

Option C. Ribosomes: Ribosomes are the sites of protein synthesis, translating mRNA into polypeptide chains. While they initiate the protein production process, they do not sort proteins to their final destinations. They create proteins but don't determine where they ultimately go.

 

Option D. Nuclear Membrane: The nuclear membrane regulates transport between the nucleus and cytoplasm through nuclear pore complexes. While it controls the movement of proteins into and out of the nucleus, it is not responsible for general protein sorting throughout the cell.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Golgi apparatus serves as the cell's central distribution hub, receiving newly synthesized proteins, modifying them through processes like glycosylation, and then sorting and directing them to their appropriate cellular or extracellular destinations based on specific targeting signals.

questions.text: A young male with a H/o dyslipidemia having ABC-A1 mutation shows the following. See the image and tell the diagnosis. (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tangier’s disease

 

Tangier's disease is an inherited disorder characterized by significantly reduced levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) in the blood. This condition can lead to the accumulation of cholesterol in various tissues and organs. Individuals with Tangier's disease may have enlarged orange tonsils and an increased risk of cardiovascular disease as shown in the picture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wolman's Disease: Wolman's disease is a severe form of lysosomal acid lipase (LAL) deficiency, a rare genetic disorder. It is characterized by the complete absence of the enzyme lysosomal acid lipase, leading to the buildup of fats in various tissues and organs. Symptoms typically appear in infancy and may include hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), splenomegaly (enlarged spleen), diarrhea/steatorrhea (fatty stools), and vomiting. This condition can be life-threatening.

 

Option B. Gaucher's Disease: Gaucher's disease is another genetic disorder caused by the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. It results in the accumulation of harmful quantities of glucocerebroside in various organs and tissues, particularly the spleen, liver, and bone marrow. Common symptoms include an enlarged spleen and liver, anemia, low platelet counts, and bone abnormalities. There are different types of Gaucher's disease, and the severity can vary.

 

Option D. Tay-Sachs Disease: Tay-Sachs disease is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the nervous system. It is caused by the absence or deficiency of an enzyme called hexosaminidase A, which leads to the buildup of a fatty substance called GM2 ganglioside in the brain and nerve cells. Symptoms typically appear in early childhood and include developmental regression, loss of motor skills, and a cherry-red spot in the eye. Tay-Sachs disease is progressive and ultimately fatal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tangier’s disease / Hypo alpha lipoproteinemia

 

ABC-A1 transporters are required for efflux of intracellular free cholesterol and phospholipids across the plasma membrane to combine with apolipoproteins, forming nascent high-density lipoprotein-cholesterol (HDL-C) particles (see fig).

 

  • So, in case of defective ABC-A1, HDL cholesterol and PL are not exported, and HDL is not properly formed causing HDL↓ (Hypo alpha-lipoproteinemia).
  • Cholesterol accumulates in reticuloendothelial system causing:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Enlarged lymph nodes
    • Large orange/ yellow tonsils (due to fat deposition)
  • The characteristic feature of Wolman’s disease is calcification of adrenals. It is also known as cholesterol ester storage disease and occurs due to deficiency of enzyme acid lipase

choices.text: Is coenzyme for pyruvate and alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
Interferes with energy production from amino acids

questions.text: Thiamine deficiency results in decreased energy production, because TPP? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Is coenzyme for pyruvate and alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

 

Pyruvate and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase use Thiamine as a co-enzyme to produce ATP using NADH.

 

Thiamine also acts as a coenzyme for transketolase in the pentose phosphate pathway (HMP shunt) but there is no ATP generation here, hence option C is correct.

 

Physiological Role of Thiamine:

 

  1. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: The co-enzyme form is thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP). It is used in oxidative decarboxylation of alpha keto acids, e.g. pyruvate dehydrogenase catalyzes the breakdown of pyruvate, to acetyl CoA, and carbon dioxide
  2. Alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: An analogous biochemical reaction that requires TPP is the oxidative decarboxylation of alpha ketoglutarate to succinyl CoA and CO2
  3. Transketolase: The second group of enzymes that use TPP as co-enzyme are the transketolases, in the hexose monophosphate shunt pathway of glucose. 
  4. The main role of thiamine (TPP) is in carbohydrate metabolism. So, the requirement of thiamine is increased along with higher intake of carbohydrates

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interferes with alcohol metabolism: While thiamine is important for alcohol metabolism, the primary reason for decreased energy production in thiamine deficiency is its role in the citric acid cycle, not alcohol metabolism.

 

Option B. Interferes with transketolase activity: Although TPP is a coenzyme for transketolase, this enzyme operates in the pentose phosphate pathway, which does not generate ATP.

 

Option D. Interferes with energy production from amino acids: Thiamine's primary role is in carbohydrate metabolism through its function in the citric acid cycle, not directly in amino acid metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiamine deficiency leads to decreased energy production because thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) is a critical coenzyme for pyruvate and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase in the citric acid cycle, essential for ATP generation.

choices.text: Creatinine clearance is lesser than Inulin clearance
Creatinine clearance is equal to Inulin clearance
Creatinine clearance is greater than Inulin clearance

questions.text: Which of the following is true? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Creatinine clearance is greater than Inulin clearance

 

Explanation:

 

Creatinine clearance slightly overestimates GFR compared to inulin clearance. This is because, in addition to being filtered at the glomerulus, a small amount of creatinine is secreted by the renal tubules, resulting in a higher clearance value.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Creatinine Clearance is Lesser than Inulin Clearance: Creatinine clearance is often slightly higher than inulin clearance. While inulin is exclusively filtered at the glomerulus and not reabsorbed or secreted, creatinine, although primarily filtered, is also slightly secreted by the renal tubules. This secretion leads to a slightly higher clearance rate compared to inulin.

 

Option B. Creatinine Clearance is Equal to Inulin Clearance: Although creatinine clearance is frequently used as a practical estimate of the glomerular filtration rate (GFR), it is not exactly equal to inulin clearance. Inulin clearance is a more accurate measure of GFR as it is neither reabsorbed nor secreted, whereas creatinine is slightly secreted.

 

Option D. None of the Above: The correct statement is that creatinine clearance is greater than inulin clearance, as explained above.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creatinine and inulin are both substances that are used to measure kidney function. Creatinine is a waste product of muscle metabolism, while inulin is a plant-derived polysaccharide that is not normally produced by the human body.

 

Creatinine clearance is a measure of the rate at which creatinine is cleared from the blood by the kidneys, while inulin clearance is a measure of the rate at which inulin is cleared from the blood by the kidneys. In theory, the clearance rates of these two substances should be equal, as they are both freely filtered by the glomerulus (the filtering unit of the kidney) and are not reabsorbed or secreted by the tubules but in practice, creatinine clearance is generally slightly higher due to the tubular secretion of creatinine and the possibility of incomplete urine collection during the clearance test.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 574

questions.text: Cherry red spot without organomegaly is seen in which of the following disorders? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tay-Sachs disease

 

Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme Hexosaminidase A. This condition leads to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in the neurons, which can be observed as a cherry red spot in the macula of the retina. However, unlike other sphingolipidoses, Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by the absence of hepatosplenomegaly.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fabry's disease: Fabry's disease is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme α-Galactosidase and is an X-linked recessive disorder. This condition does not typically present with a cherry red spot and is associated with other symptoms such as angiokeratomas and renal complications.

 

Option C. Gaucher's disease: Gaucher's disease results from a deficiency in the enzyme β-Glucosidase. It is typically associated with hepatosplenomegaly, and while cherry red spots can rarely be seen, it is not a common feature of the disease. The presence of hepatosplenomegaly distinguishes it from Tay-Sachs disease.

 

Option D. Von Gierke disease: Von Gierke disease (Glycogen storage disease type I) is not a lysosomal storage disorder or a sphingolipidosis. It is associated with glycogen metabolism and does not present with cherry red spots. This disease also features hepatomegaly, which is not consistent with the condition described in the question.

 

Additional Information

 

  • All sphingolipidoses are autosomal recessive except for Fabry's disease, which is X-linked recessive.
  • All sphingolipidoses are associated with mental retardation except for Gaucher's disease and Fabry's disease.
  • All sphingolipidoses have hepatosplenomegaly except for Tay-Sachs and Krabbe's disease.
  • All sphingolipidoses have a cherry red spot in the eye except for Fabry's and Gaucher's disease.
  • Sphingolipidoses with angiokeratoma include GM1 gangliosidosis and Fabry's disease.
  • Krabbe's disease is also known as Globoid cell leukodystrophy.
  • Sphingolipidoses resembling rheumatoid arthritis or idiopathic juvenile arthritis include Farber's disease.
  • Sphingolipidoses resembling sickle cell crisis include Fabry's disease.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by the presence of a cherry red spot in the retina without organomegaly.

 

Niemann-Pick disease - characterized by the presence of a cherry red spot in the retina with splenomegaly.

questions.text: A patient was suspected of having ALK-positive non-small cell lung cancer. The image shows a diagnostic technique used to detect ALK gene rearrangement. What technique is shown in the image? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fluorescent in situ hybridization

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows FISH analysis demonstrating ALK gene rearrangement. In ALK FISH testing, a break-apart probe design is used where the 5' and 3' ends of the ALK gene are labeled with different fluorochromes (typically red and green). A split signal pattern showing separate red and green signals (indicated by arrows) is indicative of ALK gene rearrangement, while fused yellow signals represent the normal, intact ALK gene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RNA sequencing:

  • While RNA sequencing can detect ALK fusion transcripts, it cannot provide direct visualization of gene rearrangements at the chromosomal level like FISH.
  • Relevance: RNA-seq is useful for detecting gene fusions but requires different methodology and doesn't produce fluorescent microscopy images.

 

Option C. PCR amplification:

  • PCR can detect ALK fusions but requires prior knowledge of fusion partners and cannot visualize chromosomal breaks directly.
  • Relevance: PCR is a molecular technique that doesn't provide visual confirmation of gene rearrangements.

 

Option D. Next-generation sequencing:

  • NGS can detect ALK rearrangements but uses different methodology based on DNA/RNA sequencing rather than fluorescent probe hybridization.
  • Relevance: NGS provides comprehensive genomic data but doesn't generate fluorescent microscopy images.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

FISH is the gold standard for detecting ALK gene rearrangements in NSCLC. The break-apart probe design allows direct visualization of gene rearrangements, where separated signals indicate a chromosomal break within the ALK gene region. This technique is crucial for identifying patients who might benefit from ALK-targeted therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is autosomal dominant? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Achondroplasia

 

Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a mutation of the fibroblast growth factor receptor-3 (FGFR-3) gene.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duchene muscular dystrophy – XLR

 

Option A. Cystic fibrosis & Option C. Sickle cell anemia – Autosomal recessive

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: DNA Methylation is not involved in?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Base pair excision

 

Base pair excision repair (BER) is a mechanism that corrects DNA damage involving small, non-helix-distorting base lesions. This process is initiated by DNA glycosylases that recognize and remove damaged bases, followed by endonuclease activity, DNA synthesis, and ligation. DNA methylation does not play a direct role in this repair pathway.

 

DNA methylation is usually associated with triggering histone deacetylation, chromatin condensation, and gene silencing. Differentially methylated cytosines give rise to distinct patterns specific for each tissue type and disease state. Such methylation-variable positions (MVPs) are not uniformly distributed throughout our genome, but are concentrated among genes that regulate transcription, growth, metabolism, differentiation, and oncogenesis. Alterations in MVP methylation status create epigenetic patterns that appear to regulate gene expression profiles during cell differentiation, growth, and development, as well as in cancer.

 

Environmental stressors including toxins, as well as microbial and viral exposures, can change epigenetic patterns and thereby effect changes in gene activation and cell phenotype.

It is involved in mismatch repair but not in the base pair excision repair mechanism.

 

Other Options:

 

Roles of DNA Methylation:

 

Option A. Chromatin Remodeling: DNA methylation is involved in chromatin remodeling by recruiting proteins such as methyl-CpG-binding domain proteins (MBDs) that interact with histone deacetylases (HDACs), leading to chromatin condensation and gene silencing.

 

Option B. Mismatch Repair: DNA methylation marks newly synthesized DNA strands during replication, aiding in the identification and repair of mismatches.

 

Option C. Gene Silencing: DNA methylation typically leads to gene silencing by preventing the binding of transcription factors and promoting the formation of a condensed chromatin structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA methylation is not involved in the base pair excision repair mechanism. Instead, it plays significant roles in chromatin remodeling, mismatch repair, and gene silencing by modifying the DNA structure and influencing protein interactions and gene expression.

questions.text: A known patient of tuberculosis, on INH for the past 3 months complains of numbness, tingling and burning sensation in all the extremities. What could be vitamin deficiency?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6

 

This is the correct answer. Isoniazid (INH) can lead to a deficiency in Vitamin B6. Peripheral neuropathy, which includes symptoms like numbness, tingling, and burning sensations in the extremities, is a common side effect of Vitamin B6 deficiency. Therefore, the patient's symptoms are likely a result of this deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin) Deficiency: Vitamin B12 deficiency can also cause neuropathy and neurological symptoms, but it's less likely to be associated with INH use specifically. However, it's essential to consider Vitamin B12 levels in tuberculosis patients, as they may have dietary restrictions or other factors that could lead to this deficiency.

 

Option C. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) Deficiency: Vitamin B1 deficiency can cause a condition called beriberi, which can include neurological symptoms. However, INH is not known to directly cause Vitamin B1 deficiency.

 

Option D. Vitamin B3 (Niacin) Deficiency: Niacin deficiency can lead to a condition called pellagra, which includes skin issues and neurological symptoms. INH can indirectly affect niacin levels, but it's not a common cause of niacin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Isoniazid inhibits pyridoxal phosphokinase which is required for synthesis of biologically active form of pyridoxine (B6) i.e. pyridoxal phosphate. Thus, isoniazid inhibits the formation of the active form of B6.
  • As Vit. B6 (PLP) is required for niacin (B3) synthesis from tryptophan, hence isoniazid therapy also causes Niacin deficiency.
  • In this question, best answer to mark is B6 as INH directly inhibits B6 formation.

 

Reference: Dinesh Puri 3rd ed/pg-371

questions.text: In Pompe’s disease, enzyme deficiency is? (INICET May 2023
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lysosomal acid alpha glucosidase

 

Pompe's disease, also known as glycogen storage disease type II or acid maltase deficiency, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the deficiency or absence of the enzyme lysosomal acid alpha glucosidase (also called acid alpha-glucosidase or acid maltase). This enzyme is responsible for breaking down glycogen, a complex sugar molecule, into glucose within the lysosomes of cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphofructokinase: Phosphofructokinase is an enzyme involved in the regulation of glycolysis, the metabolic pathway that breaks down glucose to produce energy in the form of ATP.

 

Option C. Muscle glycogen phosphorylase: Muscle glycogen phosphorylase is an enzyme responsible for the breakdown of glycogen in muscle tissue. Its deficiency causes McArdle’s disease.

 

Option D. Lactate dehydrogenase: Lactate dehydrogenase is an enzyme involved in the conversion of lactate, a byproduct of anaerobic metabolism, back into pyruvate, which can enter the citric acid cycle for further energy production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In individuals with Pompe's disease, the deficiency of lysosomal acid alpha glucosidase leads to the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly the muscles. This glycogen buildup affects the proper functioning of cells and tissues, causing a wide range of symptoms, primarily affecting the muscles and respiratory system.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gilbert syndrome

 

Hyperbilirubinemia refers to an elevated level of bilirubin in the blood. Bilirubin is a yellow compound that occurs in the normal catabolic pathway that breaks down heme in red blood cells. There are two types of hyperbilirubinemia based on the type of bilirubin that is elevated: conjugated (direct) and unconjugated (indirect).

 

  • Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia occurs when there is an excess of bilirubin that has not been processed by the liver. This is known as indirect bilirubin. In Gilbert syndrome, there is a reduced activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, which is responsible for converting unconjugated bilirubin into its conjugated form. As a result, patients with Gilbert syndrome have elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin, especially during periods of fasting, illness, or stress.

 

Note - Crigler Najjar Syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder of bilirubin conjugation characterized by severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that can result in bilirubin-induced neurologic dysfunction (BIND).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dubin Johnson Syndrome: This syndrome causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is characterized by defective hepatic excretion of conjugated bilirubin due to a mutation affecting the transport protein MRP2.

 

Option B. Rotor syndrome: This leads to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a rare, benign condition where there is a mild defect in bilirubin storage and transport.

 

Option C. Biliary atresia: This is a condition in which the bile ducts inside or outside the liver do not have normal openings. This leads to a buildup of conjugated bilirubin and results in conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gilbert syndrome is a cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, resulting from reduced enzyme activity that impairs the conversion of unconjugated bilirubin to its conjugated form

questions.text: In which condition is excessive urinary excretion of 5- hydroxy indole acetic acid (5HIAA) seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carcinoid syndrome

 

Carcinoid syndrome is the correct answer. It is a condition associated with the overproduction of serotonin by certain tumors, known as carcinoid tumors. Elevated serotonin levels can lead to increased 5HIAA excretion in the urine. This condition is known for causing flushing, diarrhea, and other symptoms.

 

5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5HIAA) is a metabolite of serotonin, a neurotransmitter that is produced in the enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal tract. In normal circumstances, most of the serotonin produced in the enterochromaffin cells is metabolized in the liver and then excreted in the urine as 5HIAA. However, in carcinoid syndrome, serotonin-secreting tumors can produce excessive amounts of serotonin that overwhelm the metabolic capacity of the liver, resulting in high levels of urinary 5HIAA.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alkaptonuria is a rare genetic disorder in which homogentisic acid is not properly metabolized, leading to its accumulation in various tissues and the urine. This condition is not related to serotonin metabolism.

 

Option B. Albinism is a genetic disorder that results in reduced or absent production of melanin, the pigment that gives color to the skin, hair, and eyes. This condition is also not related to serotonin metabolism.

 

Option D. Phenylketonuria is an inherited metabolic disorder in which the body cannot properly process the amino acid phenylalanine. This results in the accumulation of toxic byproducts that can lead to intellectual disability, seizures, and other serious health problems. This condition is also not related to serotonin metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carcinoid syndrome leads to the overproduction of serotonin by carcinoid tumors, resulting in increased levels of its metabolite, 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5HIAA), in the urine, which is a diagnostic marker for this syndrome.

questions.text: A young patient came with complaints of acute abdominal pain on and off and tingling sensation of limbs and at times weakness of limbs. She had a history of eating paint from the wall of a newly built house. Which of the following enzyme defect will be the cause of her condition? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ALA dehydratase

 

The given clinical history is suggestive of lead poisoning and lead is known to inhibit ALA dehydratase enzyme activity (zinc-containing enzyme).

 

Lead is the most common environmental poison in India. Paint is the major source for exposure, especially in children.

 

More than 10 mg/dL in children and more than 25 mg/dL in adults leads to toxic manifestations.

Anemia, abdominal colic and loss of appetite are very common symptoms.

 

Lead inhibits heme synthesis. Basophilic stippling of red cells is seen in the peripheral blood and bone marrow smears. This is due to the agglutination of ribosomes. Globin synthesis is adversely affected. Lead particularly inhibits ALA-dehydratase and ferrochelatase. Lifespan of RBC is shortened. Anemia enhances lead absorption, lead in turn produces more anemia; thus, a vicious cycle is operating. Lead will inhibit absorption of iron and calcium.

 

Treatment - Calcium dodecyl edetate (Calcium disodium versenate), penicillamine and dimercaprol (BAL) are used as antidotes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ALA synthase: This enzyme catalyzes the first step in heme synthesis but is not directly inhibited by lead.

 

Option C. Heme synthase: Also known as ferrochelatase, this enzyme inserts iron into protoporphyrin IX to form heme. Although lead inhibits this enzyme, ALA dehydratase is more significantly affected in lead poisoning, causing the symptoms described.

 

Option D. Coproporphyrinogen oxidase: This enzyme catalyzes a later step in heme synthesis and is not primarily affected in lead poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead poisoning inhibits ALA dehydratase, causing symptoms such as abdominal pain, tingling, and weakness of limbs. Paint ingestion, particularly in children, is a significant source of lead exposure.

questions.text: In a reaction, the substrate is available in a concentration that is 1000 times the Km value of the enzyme. After 9 minutes of reaction, 1% of substrate is converted to product (12 microgram/ml). If the concentration of the enzyme is changed to 1/3 and concentration of substrate is doubled, what is the time taken to convert the substrate into the same amount of product that i.e., 12 microgram/ml? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 27 minutes

 

The time taken for the formation of the same amount of product is 27 minutes.

 

When the substrate concentration is much greater than the Km value, the rate of the reaction is independent of the substrate concentration i.e., it follows zero-order kinetics. In this reaction, the substrate concentration is 1000 times the Km value therefore it follows zero-order kinetics. So, doubling the substrate concentration does not change the velocity of the reaction.

 

The rate of the reaction is directly proportional to the concentration of the enzyme. As the enzyme concentration becomes 1/3rd, the velocity of the reaction also becomes 1/3rd.

 

Therefore, the time taken for the formation of the same amount of product will become tripled. That is, 9 × 3 = 27 minutes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In zero-order kinetics, the reaction rate is independent of substrate concentration but directly proportional to enzyme concentration. Reducing the enzyme concentration to 1/3 increases the time taken to produce the same amount of product by a factor of 3.

questions.text: Deamination of methylated cytosine will form: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thymine

 

  • Deamination of methylated cytosine results in the conversion of cytosine to thymine. This process is important in DNA repair mechanisms and helps maintain the integrity of the genetic code. Thymine is one of the four standard nucleobases in DNA and pairs with adenine in DNA base pairing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uracil: Uracil is not formed from the deamination of methylated cytosine. Uracil is one of the four standard nucleobases in RNA and is not a product of cytosine deamination.

 

Option B. Guanine: Guanine is another nucleobase and is not produced by the deamination of methylated cytosine.

 

Option C. Adenine: Adenine is one of the four standard nucleobases in DNA and RNA and is not the product of cytosine deamination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thymine is a pyrimidine. The structure of different pyrimidines can be shown as:

 

 

Now, it is clear from the figure below that if methylated cytosine is deaminated it will form thymine as:

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 323

questions.text: The UGA codon signals: (NEET PG  2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Termination of protein synthesis

 

Explanation:

 

UGA is one of the three stop codons (along with UAA and UAG) in the standard genetic code. These stop codons signal the termination of protein synthesis by binding to release factors rather than tRNAs, causing the completed polypeptide chain to be released from the ribosome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Initiation of transcription: This is incorrect because transcription initiation occurs at promoter regions in DNA and involves RNA polymerase, not codons like UGA which function at the level of translation.

 

Option B. Elongation of polypeptide: This is incorrect because UGA doesn't code for an amino acid in the standard genetic code and therefore cannot contribute to polypeptide elongation. Interestingly, in mitochondrial DNA, UGA codes for tryptophan rather than serving as a stop codon.

 

Option C. Initiation of protein synthesis: This is incorrect because protein synthesis initiation is signaled by the start codon AUG (which codes for methionine), not by UGA.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In the standard genetic code, UGA is one of three stop codons that signal the termination of protein synthesis by triggering the release of the completed polypeptide chain from the ribosome.

questions.text: A healthcare professional nurse was ordered by a doctor to take patient’s blood sample for glucose estimation. She took this patient’s sample at 8 a.m. which of the following is used to inhibit glycolysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sodium fluoride


When a blood sample is taken for glucose estimation, it’s important to prevent glycolysis (the breakdown of glucose by red blood cells and leukocytes after collection), because glycolysis would artificially lower the measured glucose level.
 

Sodium fluoride is the most commonly used glycolysis inhibitor in blood collection tubes for glucose testing.
 

Mechanism: It inhibits the enzyme enolase in the glycolysis pathway, effectively halting glucose breakdown.
 

Often combined with potassium oxalate (an anticoagulant) in a gray-top tube for glucose measurement.

 

Other options:


Option A. Sodium citrate – Anticoagulant used mainly for coagulation studies (e.g., PT, aPTT). It works by binding calcium, not by inhibiting glycolysis.
 

Option B. Potassium oxalate – Anticoagulant that binds calcium, but does not stop glycolysis on its own. It’s used in combination with sodium fluoride in gray-top tubes.
 

Option D. EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) – Anticoagulant used for hematology tests (CBC, ESR). It binds calcium but doesn’t prevent glycolysis.
 

Educational Objective:

 

 

When a blood sample is taken for glucose estimation, it’s important to prevent glycolysis (the breakdown of glucose by red blood cells and leukocytes after collection), because glycolysis would artificially lower the measured glucose level.

questions.text: Which modification will lead to Various short and long-acting analogs of the hormone given in the picture ?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Change in 29-30 in B chain 

 

Explanation:

 

The hormone depicted in the image is insulin.  

 

Insulin's primary structure consists of two polypeptide chains: the A chain (21 amino acids) and the B chain (30 amino acids).  

 

There are two interchain disulfide bonds: 

  • Between the 7th amino acid of the A chain and the 7th amino acid of the B chain. 
  • Between the 20th amino acid of the A chain and the 19th amino acid of the B chain. One intrachain disulfide bond exists between the 6th and 11th amino acids of the A chain. 

Modifications in amino acids 29-30 of the B chain result in the production of short- and long-acting insulin types, depending on the changes made 

 

Other Options Explanation: 

 

Option A. Hydrolysis of disulphide bonds: Disrupts the structural integrity of insulin, leading to loss of biological activity. 

 

Option B. Change in 5-6 in A chain: Changing the sequence in the critical A chain can affect the folding and activity of insulin. 

 

Option D. Change in 14-16 in A chain: Changing the sequence in the A chain can disrupt the structure and function of insulin. 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient presents with a clinical scenario of obstructive jaundice. Which of the following results can be seen on Van der Bergh's reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Direct positive

 

In obstructive jaundice, the Van den Bergh reaction may show a positive result for direct bilirubin. Direct bilirubin is also known as conjugated bilirubin, and it is water-soluble. Elevated levels of direct bilirubin in the blood can be an indicator of liver or biliary tract dysfunction, which is often seen in obstructive jaundice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Indirect positive: Indirect bilirubin, also known as unconjugated bilirubin, is typically associated with hemolytic disorders rather than obstructive jaundice. Therefore, in the context of obstructive jaundice, the Van den Bergh reaction may not show a positive result for indirect bilirubin.

 

Option C. Both positive: In the context of obstructive jaundice, it's more common for the Van den Bergh reaction to show a positive result for direct bilirubin (conjugated bilirubin) rather than indirect bilirubin. However, if there is a combination of liver dysfunction and hemolysis, both direct and indirect bilirubin levels may be elevated, resulting in both being positive on the Van den Bergh reaction.

 

Option D. Coproporphyrin: Coproporphyrin is not typically measured using the Van den Bergh reaction. It is a different component related to porphyrin metabolism and is not directly associated with the assessment of bilirubin levels in obstructive jaundice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Van den Bergh reaction is a chemical reaction used to measure bilirubin levels in blood, specifically amount of conjugated bilirubin in the blood.

 

Principle: bilirubin reacts with diazotized sulphanilic acid to produce purple colored azobilirubin. This reaction is highly useful in understanding the nature of jaundice.

 

This test helps to identify the type of jaundice –

 

  1. The serum of the patient is mixed with diazo reagent. If a red color develops immediately, it is called a direct positive. It happens if conjugated bilirubin is present.
  2. In an indirect positive test, the patient's serum is first treated with alcohol and later mixed with diazo reagent. This causes development of a red color. It is seen if unconjugated bilirubin is present.
  3. If both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin are present the reaction is termed a biphasic reaction.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an amino acid-derived neurotransmitter? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Creatine

 

The question asks which of the listed options is not a neurotransmitter derived from amino acids. To answer this, let's break down each of the options:

 

  • Dopamine is a well-known neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid tyrosine. Tyrosine is first converted to DOPA, which then converts to dopamine. Dopamine plays various roles in the brain, including involvement in reward, motivation, and the pathophysiology of schizophrenia.
  • Serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine) is derived from the amino acid tryptophan. Tryptophan is converted into 5-hydroxytryptophan, which is then decarboxylated to form serotonin. Serotonin is involved in mood regulation, sleep, and other functions.
  • GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) is an inhibitory neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid glutamate. The conversion of glutamate to GABA involves a decarboxylation reaction that requires vitamin B6 as a cofactor. GABA plays a crucial role in reducing neuronal excitability throughout the nervous system.
  • Creatine, however, is not a neurotransmitter. While creatine is synthesized from the amino acids glycine, arginine, and methionine, it functions primarily as a molecule that helps to supply energy to cells, particularly muscle cells, by regenerating ATP (adenosine triphosphate). Creatine is not involved in neurotransmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dopamine: Incorrect, because it is a neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid tyrosine.

 

Option B. Serotonin: Incorrect, because it is a neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid tryptophan.

 

Option C. GABA: Incorrect, because it is a neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid glutamate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creatine is not a neurotransmitter. It is a molecule that plays a key role in energy metabolism, particularly in muscle cells, but it does not function in neurotransmission. Dopamine, serotonin, and GABA, on the other hand, are all neurotransmitters derived from amino acids.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the OPD as he is always fatigued and has muscle cramps after exercise and the blood sample collected soon after exercise showed low glucose and lactate level. He became normal after resting for a while. Which of the following diseases is he most likely to be suffering from? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) McArdle disease

 

McArdle disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type V): This condition is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme myophosphorylase, which is essential for breaking down glycogen into glucose for energy during exercise. In McArdle disease, individuals experience muscle cramps, fatigue, and myoglobinuria (the presence of myoglobin in the urine) after exercise due to the inability to access stored glycogen for energy. Low glucose levels and lactate buildup can occur during exercise in individuals with this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hers disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type VI): Hers disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme liver glycogen phosphorylase. It primarily affects the liver and leads to difficulties in releasing glucose from glycogen stores in the liver. This condition typically does not manifest with muscle symptoms like cramps or exercise-induced symptoms.

 

Option C. Cori's disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type III): Cori's disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme debranching enzyme. It primarily affects the liver and muscles and can lead to muscle weakness, liver enlargement, and hypoglycemia. However, it does not typically present with the specific exercise-induced symptoms described in the case.

 

Option D. Andersen disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type IV): Andersen disease is a rare condition caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glycogen branching enzyme. It primarily affects the liver and can result in liver fibrosis. It does not typically cause muscle cramps or exercise-induced symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient has multiple tendon xanthomas. Serum cholesterol (398 mg/dl) & LDL (220 mg/dl) were found to be raised. Statins were given to this patient. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Familial hypercholesterolemia

 

  • Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is a genetic disorder characterized by significantly elevated levels of LDL cholesterol in the blood. Tendon xanthomas are a common feature of FH. Statins are commonly prescribed to lower LDL cholesterol levels in FH patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipoprotein lipase deficiency: Lipoprotein lipase deficiency is a different condition that affects the breakdown of triglycerides in lipoproteins, not cholesterol metabolism. It does not typically present with tendon xanthomas.

 

Option C. Tangier's disease: Tangier's disease is a rare genetic disorder that leads to very low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol. It does not typically present with elevated LDL cholesterol levels or tendon xanthomas.

 

Option D. Huntington's disease: Huntington's disease is a neurological disorder and is not related to cholesterol metabolism or tendon xanthomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All of the conditions i.e. tendon xanthomas, high serum cholesterol and LDL levels and statin therapy which is given to inhibit rate limiting enzyme HMG CoA reductase of cholesterol biosynthesis indicate that cholesterol is raised in this patient. So, the most probable diagnosis is Familial hypercholesterolemia aka Type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia that occur due to deficiency of LDL receptor on liver or Apo B100 mutation.

 

Lipoprotein lipase deficiency or Apo C- II defect cause familial hyperchylomicronemia or Type I hyperlipoproteinemia with raised plasma chylomicrons and TG levels.

 

In Tangier’s disease, there is defect in ABCA1 receptors causing low levels of plasma HDL.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 258

questions.text: The best method to measure HbA1c is? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ion exchange chromatography

 

Glycated hemoglobin (GHB), reported as hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), is a biochemical marker that is used routinely in the management of individuals with diabetes mellitus to monitor long-term glycemic control and assess the risk of developing complications.

 

The fraction of hemoglobin glycated, normally about 5%, is proportionate to blood

glucose concentration. Since the half-life of an erythrocyte is typically 60 days, the level of glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) reflects the mean blood glucose concentration over the preceding 6–8 weeks.

 

Four basic types of methods are used most commonly to measure HbA1c: immunoassay, ion-exchange high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), boronate affinity HPLC, and enzymatic assays.

 

Ion-exchange HPLC separates Hb species based on charge differences between HbA1c and other hemoglobins. It is considered as a gold standard for HbA1c analysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoelectric focusing:

  • Function: Separates proteins based on their isoelectric points.
  • Limitation: Not commonly used for HbA1c measurement due to complexity and lower specificity for glycated hemoglobin.

 

Option B. Affinity chromatography:

  • Function: Uses specific binding interactions to separate molecules.
  • Limitation: While effective in some contexts, it is not the most common method for routine HbA1c measurement.

 

Option D. Electrophoresis:

  • Function: Separates proteins based on their size and charge under an electric field.
  • Limitation: Not as specific or reliable for HbA1c measurement compared to ion-exchange HPLC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ion-exchange chromatography is considered the gold standard for measuring HbA1c due to its high accuracy and ability to separate HbA1c from other hemoglobin variants based on charge differences.

questions.text: Insulin inhibits which of the following lipase enzymes? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hormone sensitive lipase

 

Insulin inhibits hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL). Hormone-sensitive lipase is responsible for the breakdown of triglycerides stored in adipose tissue into fatty acids and glycerol. When insulin levels are high, such as after a meal, it promotes fat storage and inhibits HSL activity, reducing the release of fatty acids from adipose tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lipoprotein lipase: Insulin activates lipoprotein lipase (LPL). Lipoprotein lipase is an enzyme that plays a crucial role in the metabolism of lipoproteins, specifically in the hydrolysis of triglycerides in circulating chylomicrons and very low-density lipoproteins (VLDL). Insulin promotes LPL activity, which facilitates the uptake of fatty acids into adipose tissue and muscle for storage and energy utilization.

 

Option C. Acid lipase: Insulin does not have a direct inhibitory effect on acid lipase. Acid lipase enzymes, such as gastric lipase and lysosomal lipase, function in different environments and processes compared to the regulation of lipids by insulin in the bloodstream.

 

Option D. Alkaline lipase: Insulin does not have a direct inhibitory effect on alkaline lipase. Alkaline lipases are typically found in the pancreas and function in the digestion of dietary fats. They are not directly regulated by insulin in the same way as the lipases involved in adipose tissue and circulating lipoprotein metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulin is an anabolic hormone so activates anabolic enzymes and inhibits catabolic enzymes. Hormone sensitive lipase is a catabolic enzyme present in adipose tissue cells which causes release of fatty acids from stored TG during starvation. So, it is activated by catabolic enzyme Glucagon. Lipoprotein lipase on the other hand is an anabolic enzyme and release FA from TG of VLDL and chylomicrons in fed state. Understanding the regulatory role of insulin in lipase enzymes is essential for medical students. Insulin inhibits hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) to promote fat storage and activates lipoprotein lipase (LPL) to facilitate fatty acid uptake, which helps maintain energy homeostasis and lipid metabolism in the body.

 

Ref- Harper 31st e/p 240, 245

questions.text: Which of the following should be avoided by a patient of fish odor syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Choline

 

Choline should be avoided by patients with fish odor syndrome. Choline is metabolized in the body to trimethylamine (TMA), which is responsible for the fishy odor in individuals with TMAU. Therefore, reducing choline intake can help manage the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biotin: Biotin is not typically associated with exacerbating fish odor syndrome, so it does not need to be avoided.

 

Option C. Niacin: Niacin, also known as vitamin B3, is not directly related to fish odor syndrome. It does not need to be avoided.

 

Option D. Pantothenic Acid: Pantothenic acid, also known as vitamin B5, is not directly associated with fish odor syndrome and does not need to be avoided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fish odor syndrome (trimethylaminuria) is a metabolic syndrome caused by abnormal excretion of trimethylamine in the breath, urine, sweat, saliva and vaginal secretions. Trimethylamine is derived from the intestinal bacterial degradation of foods rich in choline and carnitine and is normally oxidized by the liver to odorless trimethylamine N-oxide which is then excreted in the urine. Impaired oxidation of trimethylamine due to the deficiency of flavin containing mono oxygenase 3 (FMO3) is thought to be the cause of the fish odor syndrome and is responsible for the smell of rotting fish.

 

Foods like eggs, liver, peanuts, meat, poultry, fish, dairy foods, pasta and rice are to be avoided.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency is responsible for osteomalacia and increased risk of dental caries? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin D

 

Explanation:

 

Vitamin D deficiency is primarily responsible for osteomalacia in adults and increased risk of dental caries. Vitamin D is essential for calcium homeostasis and proper mineralization of bone and teeth. Deficiency leads to impaired calcium absorption and inadequate mineralization, resulting in soft bones (osteomalacia) and increased susceptibility to dental caries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin K: While vitamin K is important for bone health through its role in carboxylating osteocalcin, its deficiency primarily affects blood clotting. It does not directly cause osteomalacia or dental problems.

 

Option B. Vitamin E: Vitamin E is an antioxidant vitamin. Its deficiency can cause neurological problems and hemolytic anemia but does not significantly affect bone mineralization or dental health.

 

Option C. Vitamin A: While vitamin A is important for epithelial health and vision, its deficiency causes night blindness and xerophthalmia. It does not primarily affect bone mineralization or dental health.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin D deficiency manifestations include:

  • Osteomalacia in adults
  • Rickets in children
  • Increased risk of dental caries
  • Muscle weakness
  • Impaired calcium absorption
  • Increased risk of fractures
  • Secondary hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: A couple presents to the OPD with their 4-year-old child who has self-mutilating behavior and poor growth. Identify the condition and enzyme involved in it: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HGPRT deficiency

 

The child’s symptoms of self-mutilating behavior and poor growth are characteristic of Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome. This is a rare inherited disorder caused by a complete deficiency of the enzyme Hypoxanthine-Guanine Phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). This enzyme is crucial in the purine salvage pathway, where it recycles purines into nucleotides rather than letting them degrade into uric acid.

 

When HGPRT is deficient, purines like hypoxanthine and guanine accumulate and are subsequently converted to uric acid, leading to hyperuricemia and gout.
