The neurological manifestations, including self-mutilation and mental retardation, arise due to the deficiency in purine recycling, which is critical for proper brain function.

 

 

Note –

 

  • Xanthine oxidase is inhibited by allopurinol
  • The enzyme for salvage pathway is HGPRT

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Homogentisic Acid Oxidase: Deficiency in this enzyme causes Alkaptonuria, not Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome. Alkaptonuria is characterized by dark urine, ochronosis, and arthritis, not self-mutilation or poor growth.

 

Option C. Phenylalanine Hydroxylase: Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Phenylketonuria (PKU), which is characterized by intellectual disability and a musty body odor due to the accumulation of phenylalanine, but not self-mutilation or gout.

 

Option D. Benzoyl Acidase: This is not a relevant enzyme in this context, and its mention is incorrect or misleading.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome is caused by a complete deficiency of HGPRT, leading to self-mutilation, poor growth, hyperuricemia, and gout.

questions.text: The sequence of vitamin D synthesis is? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Skin- Liver- Kidney

 

The sequence of vitamin D synthesis is skin-liver-kidney.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The synthesis of vitamin D follows the sequence of Skin → Liver → Kidney, with each organ playing a critical role in converting the precursor to its active form.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl was washing her doll with shampoo containing rotenone. Her mother noticed her in an unconscious state. Which is inhibited by the above chemical? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NADH dehydrogenase

 

Rotenone is a potent inhibitor of Complex I in the electron transport chain, which is also known as NADH dehydrogenase or NADH oxidoreductase. Complex I is responsible for transferring electrons from NADH to coenzyme Q (ubiquinone), a crucial step in cellular respiration and ATP production. By inhibiting Complex, I, rotenone disrupts the electron transport chain, leading to a significant reduction in ATP synthesis. This inhibition can result in decreased cellular energy and potential cellular damage, which explains the unconscious state observed in the child.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Succinate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is part of Complex II in the electron transport chain, which is not affected by rotenone. Complex II facilitates the transfer of electrons from succinate to coenzyme Q, bypassing Complex I, which is why rotenone does not inhibit this step.

 

Option C. Cytochrome C: Cytochrome C is a small heme protein that plays a role in electron transfer between Complex III and Complex IV of the electron transport chain. Rotenone does not affect Cytochrome C, as it acts upstream at Complex I.

 

Option D. Cytochrome oxidase: Also known as Complex IV, this enzyme is responsible for transferring electrons from Cytochrome C to oxygen, the final electron acceptor. Inhibitors of Complex IV include cyanide and carbon monoxide, not rotenone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rotenone specifically inhibits Complex I also known as NADH CoQ oxidoreductase (NADH dehydrogenase) in the electron transport chain, blocking electron flow and ATP production.

questions.text:
True regarding mitochondrial DNA? (INICET Nov 2021)

 

  1. Higher chances of mutations as compared to the nuclear genome
  2. Single stranded Circular DNA
  3. mt codons are slightly different from nuclear DNA codons
  4. mtDNA encodes for all the ETC complex proteins
  5. Has around 16,000 base pairs
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A, C, E

 

MITOCHONDRIAL DNA         

 

Statement A. Higher chances of mutations as compared to the nuclear genome: mtDNA has a higher mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA due to the lack of introns and protective histone proteins, which help prevent mutations in nuclear DNA.

 

Statement C. mt codons are slightly different from nuclear DNA codons: mtDNA uses a slightly different genetic code. For example, the codon UGA, which is a stop codon in the universal genetic code, codes for tryptophan in mtDNA. Similarly, AGG and AGA code for arginine in the universal genetic code but are stop codons in mtDNA. AUA codes for isoleucine in the universal genetic code but codes for methionine in mtDNA.

 

 

Statement E. Has around 16,000 base pairs: mtDNA contains approximately 16,000 base pairs and 37 genes, which make up about 1% of the total cellular DNA.

                                   

Other Statements:

 

Statement B. Single stranded Circular DNA: This statement is incorrect. mtDNA is circular but double-stranded.

 

Statement D. mtDNA encodes for all the ETC complex proteins: This statement is incorrect. mtDNA encodes for only 13 of the 67 proteins required for the electron transport chain (ETC), which is approximately 19% of the total.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial DNA has a higher mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA, has a slightly different genetic code, and contains around 16,000 base pairs, encoding for a portion but not all of the proteins required for the electron transport chain.

questions.text: Cystic fibrosis is caused by which of the following deletion? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phenylalanine at 508

 

  • Correct. Cystic fibrosis is primarily caused by the deletion of Phenylalanine at position 508 in the CFTR gene. This mutation leads to a malfunctioning CFTR protein, which results in the characteristic symptoms of cystic fibrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tyrosine at 508: Cystic fibrosis is not caused by the deletion of Tyrosine at position 508. The critical deletion is of Phenylalanine at this position.

 

Option C. Tryptophan at 508: Cystic fibrosis is not caused by the deletion of Tryptophan at position 508. The deletion of Phenylalanine at this position is the key mutation associated with cystic fibrosis.

 

Option D. Lysine at 805: Cystic fibrosis is not caused by the deletion of Lysine at position 805. The F508del mutation is the most common and well-known mutation in cystic fibrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystic fibrosis is due to mutation in cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein by deletion of one codon which give rise to phenylalanine at position 508 of this protein. Mnemonic: F-fibrosis, F- Phenylalaine

 

This protein helps in movement of H2O and chloride ion in and out of cell and helps in the formation of mucus secretion and saliva.

 

In normal conditions, the channel allows the formation of thin layer of mucus. But in cystic fibrosis, a thick layer of mucus is formed (see fig) causing airway obstruction leading to infection and ultimately scarring of lung tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following Amino acid needs to be supplied in the diet of patients with Cystathionine beta synthase defect? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cysteine

 

Cysteine is not typically restricted in the diet of patients with CBS deficiency. In fact, cysteine supplementation may be necessary in some cases because CBS deficiency can lead to a decreased ability to convert homocysteine into cysteine. However, this decision is made on an individual basis after assessing the patient's specific needs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methionine: Methionine is usually restricted in the diet of patients with CBS deficiency. Since methionine is metabolized to homocysteine, limiting dietary methionine intake can help reduce homocysteine levels in these patients.

 

Option C. Serine: Serine is not typically restricted in the diet of CBS-deficient patients. It is not directly related to homocysteine metabolism, so it does not require special dietary adjustments.

 

Option D. Homocysteine: Homocysteine is not supplied in the diet but rather accumulates in the body as a result of CBS deficiency. Managing and reducing elevated homocysteine levels is the primary goal of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystathionine beta synthase (CBS) is involved in the synthesis of cysteine from dietary methionine. Cysteine synthesis require methionine, serine and vitamin B6. The reactions are summarized in the diagram:

 

 

So, in case of CBS deficiency there will be no formation of cystathionine and cysteine. so, cysteine becomes essential and needs to be taken in diet.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 291

choices.text: Valine substituted by glutamate at 6th position
Valine substituted by glutamate at 5th position
Glutamate substituted by valine at 5th position
Glutamate substituted by valine at 6th position

questions.text: A patient was in excruciating pain all over the body and went to hospital. This pain occurs after exercise. Patient has anemia with elongated RBCs. Sickle cell anemia diagnosis was made. Which of the following is true about this disease?(FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glutamate substituted by valine at 6th position

 

Explanation:

 

  • SCA is due to point mutation in the 6th codon of beta globin that leads to the replacement of a Glutamate (Polar) residue with a Valine (Nonpolar) residue
  • This substitution significantly alters the hemoglobin's physical properties, leading to the polymerization of hemoglobin under low oxygen conditions and causing the red blood cells to assume a sickle shape. These sickled cells lead to vascular occlusions and a range of complications including severe pain crises, often triggered by conditions such as strenuous exercise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnosis of SCA can be done by:

 

  • Hb electrophoresis—HbS migrate slower in an electric field because of less negative charge, because glutamate is replaced by valine
  • Sickling Test
  • HPLC to fractionate Hb
  • Isoelectric Focusing
  • Direct diagnosis by RFLP.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 657

questions.text: What mechanism is responsible for class switch recombination (CSR) in B cells? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) AID enzyme activity

 

Explanation: 

 

Class switch recombination (CSR) is primarily mediated by Activation-Induced Cytidine Deaminase (AID). AID initiates CSR by deaminating cytosine residues in switch regions, creating DNA breaks that allow recombination between different constant regions, leading to antibody class switching while maintaining antigen specificity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Somatic hypermutation: While SHM also requires AID, it specifically introduces point mutations in variable regions to increase antibody affinity. It doesn't directly cause class switching.

 

Option C. VDJ recombination: This process occurs during early B cell development to generate initial antibody diversity. It happens before class switching and uses different molecular machinery.

 

Option D. RAG enzymes: RAG1 and RAG2 are essential for VDJ recombination but are not involved in class switch recombination. They function earlier in B cell development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Class switch recombination:

  • Requires AID enzyme activity
  • Changes antibody isotype (e.g., IgM to IgG)
  • Occurs in germinal centers
  • Maintains antigen specificity
  • Involves DNA double-strand breaks
  • Different from somatic hypermutation despite sharing AID dependency

questions.text: If the RNA sequence is CAAGGU, what is the sequence of the template strand? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ACCTTG

 

Explanation:

 

The given RNA sequence is CAAGGU. To determine the template strand sequence -

  1. Direction of RNA Sequence: The RNA sequence is provided without directions, but typically the sequence is read from 5' to 3'. Thus, the sequence is 5'-CAAGGU-3'.
  2. Non-Template Strand (Coding Strand) of DNA: The non-template strand of DNA has the same sequence as the RNA transcript except for the replacement of uracil (U) with thymine (T). Therefore, the non-template strand would be 5'-CAAGGT-3'.
  3. Template Strand of DNA: The template strand of DNA is complementary to the non-template strand. Complementarity means adenine (A) pairs with thymine (T), and cytosine (C) pairs with guanine (G). Therefore, the template strand, read in the 3' to 5' direction, would be:
    • C pairs with G
    • A pairs with T
    • A pairs with T
    • G pairs with C
    • G pairs with C
    • U (in RNA) pairs with A (in DNA, U replaced by T in RNA, so G pairs with C)

 

Therefore, the template strand is 3'-GTTAAC-5'. When we reverse the direction to match the 5' to 3' orientation given in the options, the sequence is ACCTTG.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CAAGGT: This option is the sequence of the non-template (coding) strand of DNA, not the template strand.

 

Option B. GTTCCA: This option is not complementary to the RNA sequence.

 

Option D. TGGAAC: This option is incorrect as it does not match the complementary base pairing rules for the given RNA sequence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The template strand of DNA is complementary to the RNA sequence and the non-template strand, with the RNA sequence transcribed from the 5' to 3' direction of the non-template strand.

choices.text: Mixed meal having all 3 in equal amount

questions.text: The maximum thermic effect is seen with a meal which has? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Protein

 

Increased heat production or increased metabolic rate following the intake of food is called as thermogenic effect of food or diet-induced thermogenesis or specific dynamic action (SDA) of food.

 

Part of this is due to the expenditure of energy for digestion; absorption and active transport of products of the digestion. Another reason for this expenditure of energy is that reserve materials, such as glycogen, triacyl glycerol, protein, etc. are synthesized from small molecules available after digestion.

 

A high protein diet leads to higher protein turnover resulting in increased diet induced thermogenesis.

 

The values of SDA are: for proteins 30%, for lipids 15%, and for carbohydrates 5%. This means that out of every 100 grams of proteins consumed, the energy available for doing useful work is 30% less than the calculated value.

It is a common experience that during hot weather following the consumption of a protein rich meal, one feels hot and humid for a while. On the other hand, in cold weather, the same would provide a comfortable feeling

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fat: Fats have a moderate thermic effect, lower than proteins.

 

Option C. Carbohydrates: Carbohydrates have the lowest thermic effect.

 

Option D. Mixed meal having all 3 in equal amount: A mixed meal would have a combined thermic effect that is a weighted average of the individual macronutrient effects, which would be lower than that of a protein-only meal.

 

Real-world Observation: It is commonly observed that after consuming a protein-rich meal, especially during hot weather, individuals may feel hot and humid due to the increased heat production. Conversely, in cold weather, the same meal can provide a warming effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maximum thermic effect is seen with protein-rich meals, as proteins require more energy for digestion, absorption, and metabolism compared to fats and carbohydrates.

questions.text: Which enzyme prevents excessive senescence? NEET PG 2015
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Telomerase

 

Explanation:

 

Telomerase is a ribonucleoprotein enzyme that maintains the length of telomeres by adding repetitive nucleotide sequences to the ends of chromosomes. This action prevents telomeres from reaching a critically short length, which would trigger cellular senescence or apoptosis. Telomerase is particularly active in stem cells and most cancer cells, enabling them to divide indefinitely. In most somatic cells, however, telomerase activity is low or absent, leading to eventual senescence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DNA Polymerase: While involved in DNA replication, it does not prevent senescence directly.

 

Option C. Catalase: An enzyme that breaks down hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen, primarily protecting cells from oxidative damage.

 

Option D. Peroxidase: Another enzyme that helps in the reduction of peroxides, not involved in telomere maintenance.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Telomerase prevents cellular senescence by maintaining telomere length.

questions.text: In SCID, what type of DNA repair is defective? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-homologous end joining repair

 

Human severe combined immune deficiency (SCID) is the most serious inherited immunological deficit which is caused due to defects in the predominant pathway for double-strand break repair called nonhomologous DNA end joining, or NHEJ.

 

Defects in DNA Repair:

 

 

Other Options: 

 

The table in the provided image highlights various DNA repair pathways and the associated cancer syndromes when these pathways are defective:

 

Option A. Base excision repair (BER):

 

  • DNA Lesion: Base modifications, abasic sites
  • Cancer Syndromes: Not yet reported

 

Option B. Nucleotide excision repair (NER):

 

  • DNA Lesion: Intra-strand crosslinks, bulky adducts
  • Cancer Syndromes: Xeroderma pigmentosum, ERCC6L2 deficiency

 

Option C. Mismatch repair (MMR):

 

  • DNA Lesion: Mismatches, indels
  • Cancer Syndromes: Constitutional MMR syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

SCID is caused by defects in the NHEJ pathway, which is responsible for repairing double-strand breaks in DNA. This defect impairs the immune system, leading to severe immunodeficiency.

 

Non-homologous end joining (NHEJ):

 

  • DNA Lesion: Double-strand breaks (DSBs)
  • Cancer Syndromes: Ligase IV deficiency, XLF/NHEJ1 deficiency, Rothmund-Thompson syndrome, Werner syndrome

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of night blindness in pediatric age? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin A deficiency

 

Explanation:

 

Night blindness, also known as nyctalopia, is the inability to see well in low light or darkness. The most common cause of night blindness in the pediatric age group is vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A is essential for the production of rhodopsin, a pigment in the retina that is crucial for vision in low-light conditions.

 

Key Points:

  • Vitamin A deficiency: Leads to inadequate production of rhodopsin, resulting in night blindness.
  • Common causes of vitamin A deficiency: Poor dietary intake, malabsorption disorders, or increased requirements during periods of rapid growth.

 

Symptoms of Vitamin A Deficiency:

  • Night blindness
  • Xerophthalmia (dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea)
  • Bitot's spots (foamy patches on the conjunctiva)
  • Keratomalacia (softening of the cornea)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin C deficiency: Causes scurvy, characterized by bleeding gums and perifollicular hemorrhages, but not night blindness.

 

Option B. Congenital glaucoma: A rare condition that can affect vision but does not specifically cause night blindness.

 

Option D. Vitamin E deficiency: Can cause neurological problems and hemolytic anemia but is not typically associated with night blindness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin A deficiency is the most common cause of night blindness in the pediatric age group, emphasizing the importance of adequate intake of vitamin A for maintaining healthy vision, especially in low-light conditions.

questions.text: Vitamin K in its coenzyme form is regenerated by the enzyme? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epoxide reductase

 

Vitamin K plays a crucial role in the carboxylation of glutamic acid residues in proteins to form gamma-carboxyglutamate, which is important for blood clotting. The active form of vitamin K is required for this carboxylation reaction. After participating in the carboxylation reaction, vitamin K is converted to its epoxide form. To be reused, this epoxide form must be converted back to its active hydroquinone form.

 

The enzyme epoxide reductase is responsible for this conversion. It reduces vitamin K epoxide back to the active hydroquinone form, thus regenerating the coenzyme form of vitamin K. This process is essential for the continuous availability of active vitamin K for carboxylation reactions.

 

 

Fig: Vitamin K cycle.

 

Dicoumarol - a structural analog inhibits vitamin K reductase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutathione reductase: This enzyme is involved in the reduction of glutathione disulfide to glutathione, and is not involved in the regeneration of vitamin K.

 

Option B. Quinone reductase: This enzyme reduces quinones to hydroquinones but is not specifically responsible for the regeneration of vitamin K's active form.

 

Option C. Vitamin K reductase: While it plays a role in the vitamin K cycle, the specific enzyme responsible for regenerating the coenzyme form of vitamin K from its epoxide form is epoxide reductase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epoxide reductase regenerates the active coenzyme form of vitamin K from its epoxide form, ensuring the continuous availability of active vitamin K for critical carboxylation reactions.

questions.text: Enzyme defect in McArdle’s Disease?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myophosphorylase

 

This is the correct answer. McArdle's Disease results from a deficiency of myophosphorylase, which is an enzyme responsible for breaking down glycogen into glucose within muscle cells. The lack of myophosphorylase impairs the ability of muscle cells to release glucose from glycogen during physical activity, leading to muscle fatigue, pain, and other symptoms typically observed in McArdle's Disease patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucose-6-phosphatase: This enzyme is involved in glucose metabolism in the liver, not in muscle cells. Deficiencies in glucose-6-phosphatase lead to other types of Glycogen Storage Diseases, such as Von Gierke's Disease (GSD Ia).

 

Option C. Glycogen synthase : While this enzyme plays a role in glycogen metabolism, it is not the enzyme affected in McArdle's Disease. Instead, it is myophosphorylase that is deficient in this condition.

 

Option D. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is involved in the initial steps of glucose metabolism but is not directly related to glycogen breakdown or McArdle's Disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

McArdle's disease is Type V glycogen storage disease that occurs due to deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase (Myophosphorylase) enzyme. In this disease, muscle glycogen cannot be used during exercise, so, on strenuous exercise there are muscles cramps. Also, normal or relatively low levels of lactate will be formed from muscle glycogen after exercise.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 167

questions.text: Monkeypox detection is best done by: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Real-Time PCR

 

Monkeypox virus is a double-stranded DNA virus, and the most effective method for detecting DNA viruses is through Real-Time PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction). Real-Time PCR allows for the rapid and precise amplification of DNA, making it a highly sensitive and specific tool for detecting the presence of the Monkeypox virus in a sample. This method can detect even small amounts of viral DNA, making it the best option for early and accurate diagnosis.

 

In cases where the pathogen is an RNA virus, the detection process typically starts with Reverse Transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR), where RNA is first converted into complementary DNA (cDNA) before amplification. However, since Monkeypox is a DNA virus, Real-Time PCR is directly applicable without the need for this additional step.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA: While ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay) is useful for detecting antibodies or antigens related to an infection, it is not the most direct or sensitive method for detecting the DNA of the Monkeypox virus.

 

Option B. Hemagglutination: Hemagglutination is a method used to detect viruses that cause red blood cells to clump together. This method is not applicable for detecting Monkeypox virus, which does not cause hemagglutination.

 

Option C. Western Blot: Western Blot is used primarily to detect specific proteins in a sample and is more commonly associated with confirming the presence of antibodies, such as in HIV testing. It is not the best method for detecting a DNA virus like Monkeypox.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Real-Time PCR is the most effective and reliable method for detecting Monkeypox virus, a double-stranded DNA virus, due to its sensitivity and specificity
